data.title: The residents charged £4,400 a year for leaf collection
data.description:
Struggling with health issues and worried about paying her mortgage, the last thing Pauline Brown needed was more bad news.

But when her service charge jumped overnight from £11 to £98 a month – equivalent to £1,176 a year – she was left at a complete loss.

With her sick pay from work at just over £400 a month, she simply couldn’t afford to cover the fee.

Brown, who owns the freehold of her house, which lies on the 173-home Ribble Road estate in south Liverpool, approached Plus Dane Housing, the housing association that manages the land, to ask why she has seen such a steep increase in price. She had lived in the property since 1986 and had only ever seen moderate annual rises – nothing close to the near-800pc rise now being demanded.

The company told her it was linked to the rising cost of living and covered grounds maintenance for the estate, including £5,150 for weed control, £5,500 for grass cutting and £4,400 for leaf collection.

All the charges had jumped by exactly 16.49pc from the year before.

“I said, ‘So £98 a month for that? Well, I’m sorry, I’m not paying it,” she says.

Plus Dane Housing insisted that Brown was responsible for one-19th of the estate, as outlined in the original transfer deeds for her house, and that she therefore had no choice but to stump up.

She has stood her ground, but now has a £1,000 debt looming over her. “It’s always in the back of my mind even though I try not to think about it,” she says.

It comes as the service charge system in Britain comes under growing scrutiny.

Amid a rise in complaints from residents across the country, Labour is planning a draft bill to strengthen the rights of both freeholders and leaseholders. It includes making charges more transparent and easier to challenge cost increases.

Suzanne Mana, co-founder of the Social Housing Action Campaign group, says the scale of issues concerning service charges is “absolutely massive”.

“If you talk to MPs, a lot will tell you that their inboxes are absolutely crammed with similar cases,” she says.

Under the current system, freeholders have no implied “test of reasonableness” to fall back on for service charges. This is unlike leaseholders, who are protected under the Landlord and Tenant Agreement Act.

It means fees can be raised at will without consultation, while any dispute has to go through the county court. Freeholders have no statutory rights to see any documentary evidence relating to charges, but are obliged to pay as typically outlined in the onerous deeds of the properties.

Halima Ali, of freeholder campaign group HorNet, claims it effectively gives housing associations and estate management companies “a licence to print money”.

“We’re not getting anything out of this apart from being cash cows. It’s soul-destroying, and we’re powerless to do anything,” she says.

Between 2019 and 2024, average service charges increased by a third, with the North West recording the second-largest rise at 57.6pc – well above the average inflation rate of 2.5pc.

At the same time, salaries at housing associations have risen.

Ian Reed, the chief executive of Plus Dane Housing, saw his annual pay rise from £182,000 in 2023 to £214,000 last year. Plus Dane Housing says Mr Reed’s salary increase reflects the fact that he had not received a pay rise since 2020.

Meanwhile, Pauline Brown is just one of a score of homeowners on the Ribble Road estate who have watched their service charge skyrocket in recent months – in one case by more than 1,100pc.

Victoria Rooney, another homeowner on the estate, was left shell-shocked after being told the bill for leaf collection was rising from £3,790 a year to £4,400.

“We’re not talking expansive landscaping here at all. I’ve counted, and there are about nine trees.”

Despite charges for litter picking rising to nearly £1,000 a year, the condition of the estate has declined, according to several residents.

“A couple of months ago, there was abandoned rubbish and trolleys and all kinds. It was just in a terrible state,” says Christina Black, whose service charge jumped from £6 to £18 after Plus Dane Housing said it had been charging her “incorrectly” in the past.

Black, who has lived on the estate for 40 years, has been battling cancer and says the whole experience has added undue stress.

“Last winter, I was really unwell, and I really didn’t know whether I was going to pull through. It took its toll on me.”

As well as fears about running up a large debt, there are also concerns that the higher charges could be affecting the value of homes on the estate.

“I know for a fact people have been selling their house, and the buyers have backed out because they said, ‘Well, we’re paying this service charge, but for what?’” says Anne, who also saw her bill triple overnight.

“I don’t mind paying a small fee if the place is kept decent.”

Plus Dane Housing says it has “dealt with several concerns and complaints in relation to the services being provided at Ribble Road” and has “taken some steps to improve them”.

They add: “Our grounds maintenance service visits 16 times per year and includes lawn mowing, hedge trimming, litter picking and leaf collection during the visits between mid-September and March.”

Claire Dixon, deputy chief executive for Plus Dane Housing, defends the inconsistency of service charges, saying the company has “a different legal relationship and a different set of obligations to meet for each customer”.

She says that Plus Dane Housing complies “with all statutory requirements for rent and service charges, which includes ensuring sufficient notice periods for informing customers of any changes” and “ensures customers only pay for the services related to that estate”.

Plus Dane Housing says while there have been general inflationary costs, “there are also a number of residents that have had their charges adjusted in line with their legal agreement, as was the case in the largest increase on the estate from £7 to £87”.

‘The Government needs to sort this’

Britain’s convoluted leasehold and freehold system has been a target for government reform for years.

In its manifesto, Labour pledged to take action to tackle “unfair maintenance costs” and give freeholders more rights to challenge service charges through tribunals.

However, although the Leasehold and Freehold Reform Act was passed in May last year, only a limited number of its provisions have been brought into effect under the current Government.

Ali, of Hornet, estimates that around three million freeholders are affected by burdensome service charges. She is worried that Labour’s pledge to build 1.5 million new homes by the end of this Parliament will leave millions more trapped.

“The Government is constantly pushing this ‘build, baby, build’ mantra, and we’re constantly saying, ‘You need to sort this issue out before you build more homes,’” she says.

Last year, a report by the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) identified issues with “high and unclear” estate management charges.

It subsequently recommended a policy of “adoption” in which councils, rather than private companies, oversee amenities on all new housing estates.

But Ali believes the policy needs to encompass all privately managed estates, both new and old, to make sure nobody is left behind.

“A lot of these people are already struggling,” she says. “This is why we need universal adoption. To help all of us who are already trapped.”

In a separate case, a parliamentary enquiry was held last week amid concerns about maintenance issues, missing reserve funds and opaque fees at FirstPort, the UK’s largest leasehold management company.

MPs heard evidence relating to alleged failures to carry out essential work, poor communication and a lack of transparency over service charge calculations and insurance costs.

A FirstPort spokesman said: “We were not given the opportunity to participate in this meeting, but we have worked closely with MPs to resolve customer enquiries and keep them updated on the changes we’re making across our business.

“This includes continued improvements of our systems, ways of working, and customer service, and making sure our teams have the right skills and qualifications.”

The Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government said it was “already consulting on detailed plans to drive up transparency of service charges” to “make it easier for leaseholders to challenge unreasonable bills”.

data.title: Miliband admits wind power less reliable than expected
data.description:
The Government has slashed forecasts for the amount of electricity it expects wind farms to generate in a blow to Ed Miliband’s net zero plans.

In documents published before an auction of green energy subsidies this week, officials said they were revising down the predicted efficiency of wind turbines by more than a quarter as a result of “updated modelling”.

Experts said the change would mean that the Energy Secretary would have to pay higher subsidies to wind farms to secure the same amount of energy, making it harder to hit Labour’s clean power targets.

The “bogus numbers” were also attacked by the Conservatives, who have called on Mr Miliband to scrap the latest subsidy auction, which they argued risked pushing up consumer bills.

Industry sources claimed developers had previously warned officials that estimates for power generation were unrealistic, but that the Government had stuck with them anyway. One said: “The numbers were statistically absurd.”

Separately on Tuesday, Spanish utilities giant Iberdrola, which owns Scottish Power, also reported a 5pc drop in UK wind farm generation because of “lower wind resource”.

A turbine’s efficiency can be affected by a variety of factors, such as wind speeds, “wind theft” from other nearby farms and how often the structures are paid to switch off to prevent over-congestion on the network.

Wind speeds have also been dropping across the UK and Europe over decades, a phenomenon known as “stilling”. However, a recent Cardiff University study found that wind speeds have begun picking up in recent years.

The Government’s new estimates slashed the predicted “load factor” – the proportion of the year turbines are expected to generate power – from 61pc to 43.6pc for offshore wind. The estimated load factor for onshore turbines was also revised down, from 48.7pc to 33.4pc.

The changes were blamed on new modelling showing that wind turbines generated less power at various wind speeds than previously thought, as well as updated assumptions on what can cause turbines to lose power.

A spokesman for the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero (DESNZ) did not address why the Government had revised its estimates down so drastically.

Claire Coutinho, the shadow energy secretary and Mr Miliband’s predecessor in the last Tory government, said: “My time in the department convinced me that the Government is relying on bogus numbers that make net zero look artificially cheap.

“I started a full system cost analysis to reveal the true cost of an energy system dependent on wind and solar, but Ed Miliband has scrapped it because he doesn’t want to know the truth. That tells you all you need to know. Bad data leads to bad policy.”

The downgrade has also raised doubts about Mr Miliband’s ability to hit his clean power targets. Labour is committed to switching the electricity system to 95pc clean power sources by 2030, a goal that will require a tripling of current offshore wind capacity alone.

Less efficient wind turbines still face the same construction costs, pushing up the amount of subsidy needed to make projects viable. Industry experts said the latest round of subsidies was not generous enough to deliver the level of wind power needed to hit the Energy Secretary’s goals.

Mr Miliband still needs to secure at least another 12 gigawatts of capacity, but RenewableUK, which represents wind farm owners, said he had only budgeted enough in the latest auction for five gigawatts.

This is significant because this year’s auction, known as allocation round 7 (AR7), is seen as one of the Energy Secretary’s last chances to acquire enough power for his target.

Kathryn Porter, an independent energy consultant, said the Government’s load factor revisions could not “change budget reality” and meant that Mr Miliband would be able to procure less capacity than last year.

She added: “You can assume higher load factors in a spreadsheet, but that doesn’t reduce the actual capital outlay or construction cost per gigawatt.”

The “likely practical outcome” was that this year’s £900m budget would “underwrite fewer gigawatts” than before, Ms Porter said.

An DESNZ spokesman stressed that the revision did not necessarily mean higher subsidies would need to be paid out, as the money is only paid out if wholesale power prices in the future fall below a certain level.

However, the Government admitted the reduced load factors did influence the maximum budget ministers were willing to set overall for offshore wind power support.

Nick Hibberd, of RenewableUK, said: “In previous auctions, load factor assumptions have been very high compared to reasonable expectations of offshore wind generation in future years.”

RenewableUK said the current actual load factor for offshore turbines was about 38pc. That figure has tended to improve over time due to improved technology and the growing use of bigger, more efficient turbines.

data.title: London private housebuilding ‘stone dead’ under Sadiq Khan
data.description:
Sir Sadiq Khan has been accused of helping to kill private housebuilding “stone dead” in London.

Former Tory mayoral candidate Lord Bailey of Paddington said housebuilding programmes in the capital had been “dire” under Sir Sadiq’s London Plan despite £9bn of backing from the previous government.

“Sadiq Khan’s policies in the London Plan ... have helped to kill private development stone dead by rendering it unviable and introducing more regulation, all in the name of ‘good growth’,” Lord Bailey said in a report published on Tuesday. “You cannot have good growth if there is no growth.”

As part of his housebuilding strategy, the Mayor set strict targets for private developments to consist of at least 35pc affordable homes. The Mayor’s London Plan also set a target for 50pc of all homes approved across London to be affordable.

Both policies have been blamed by private sector developers for making building in the capital difficult and unprofitable.

“Sadiq Khan must take responsibility for having introduced these policies,” said Lord Bailey.

He added: “We have had a housing crisis in London for many years, but what we have now is a housebuilding crisis as well. We cannot go on like this.”

Behind target

A collapse in construction levels has set Sir Sadiq vastly behind his target to build 88,000 homes a year in the capital.

Research from Molior showed just 6pc of the 176,000 homes that Mr Khan promised to build in the next two years will be built, leaving the capital with a 94pc shortfall.

London is now building the fewest homes of any English region per capita, according to Lord Bailey, and under a quarter of the rate of the rest of England.

Central government stepped in with a £300m bailout package for the Mayor of London’s housing plans last week.

Under the rescue package, affordable home targets for individual developments will be lowered to 20pc, as part of a string of emergency measures agreed with Steve Reed, the Housing Secretary.

Lord Bailey said the new target remained “unsustainable” and that it should be scrapped altogether.

His recommendations include fast-tracking construction for thousands of homes on land already owned by the Greater London Authority, Transport for London and City Hall.

Lord Bailey also urged the Government to fund the DLR extension to Thamesmead in south-east London to unlock 15,000 homes, devise a tax relief system for developers proportionate to the number of homes built, and scrap stamp duty land tax for primary residents.

Reinstating first-time buyer support and supporting more mortgage options for buyers should also be prioritised, he said.

A spokesman for the Mayor of London said: “We have started more new council homes in London than at any time since the 1970s and, prior to the pandemic, completed more new homes in London than any time since the 1930s.

“Urgent action is required, which is why the Mayor is working with the Government on a package of bold measures to boost social and affordable homes in the capital.”

A government spokesman said: “We have already announced a temporary relief from the Community Infrastructure Levy for schemes with at least 20pc affordable housing, as well as a temporary fast-track planning route for developers committing to affordable homes.

“Our measures will help kickstart thousands of homes, including affordable ones, across London.”

data.title: Flying taxi pioneer warns the West of China’s power grab
data.description:
One of the world’s leading flying taxi pioneers has warned Western officials to guard against a Chinese swoop for control of the fast-developing sector.

Joby Aviation, based in California, said it fears Beijing will seek to wrest control of the burgeoning industry by accelerating regulatory approvals for flying taxis.

In doing so, China could displace America’s Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) as the dominant regulatory authority for the craft.

Eric Allison, chief product officer of Joby Aviation, said China could gain an overwhelming advantage by exploiting technology that could employ tens of thousands of people and generate billions in revenue.

“Regulators are seeing an opportunity. The Chinese certainly are, and I think that is one of the things that we have to be a little bit careful about,” he said. 

“They are taking an approach that’s incompatible with the way the West is regulating, which has a geopolitical overlay because it could lead to polarisation into different spheres of influence.

“There are 50 companies in China, and they are looking at all sorts of things. We’ve seen this happen with electric cars, and the way technology cascades can happen.”

He cited the global drone market as another area in which China has come to dominate at the expense of Western manufacturers that once led the way.

China now makes about 90pc of commercial drones and dominates production of critical components from batteries to motors, giving it significant leverage and posing a potential security threat to the West.

Beijing is seizing on new technologies to challenge the US and European dominance of the aerospace industry that has prevailed since the Wright Brothers’ first flight in 1903.

While China lags in conventional aviation, the arrival of flying taxis offers it an opportunity to overturn the status quo.

Flying taxis – known in the industry as Electric Vertical Take-Off and Landing (eVTOL) aircraft – combine electric motors and batteries with directional propellers and jets to make flights through urban areas affordable with less noise.

China’s focus has been more on cargo eVTOLs than on the car substitutes proposed by Joby Aviation, US rival Archer and UK-based Vertical Aerospace. However, that has begun to shift.

Western nations have meanwhile taken steps towards a unified approach to the regulation of the new aircraft, with the “five eyes” intelligence alliance of Britain, the US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand forming the joint National Aviation Authority in June.

The White House also issued an executive order mandating the acceleration of safe eVTOL deployment in the US.

‘More work to be done’

Mr Allison said the developments were positive, though “there is more work to be done”.

He said it is also vital that politicians and regulators view flying taxis not as a niche product but as one that could unleash a huge new industry in years to come.

He said: “Air taxis are just the first application for all-electric power, which happens to be really exciting and which everyone wants to see happen.

“But it’s not just a nice thing to do. This technology will be foundational for the next era of aviation. The great transitions in this industry have come on the heels of new propulsion systems.”

Mr Allison said the FAA is aware of the risks and has been “leaning in harder than ever” despite changes in personnel as part of Donald Trump’s efforts to shrink the federal workforce.

Britain’s Civil Aviation Authority also appears “enthusiastic” about the eVTOL sector after regaining its status as an independent regulator following Brexit, he said.

Joby Aviation, which has an outline deal to supply flying taxis to Virgin Atlantic for flights between Heathrow and the City, is planning its first commercial services in the United Arab Emirates.

data.title: Property tax raid ‘puts 120,000 high street jobs at risk’
data.description:
Rachel Reeves’s £1.7bn property tax raid will put 120,000 high street jobs at risk, retail and hospitality bosses have warned.

The British Retail Consortium (BRC) and UK Hospitality have raised fresh concerns over the Chancellor’s plans to impose higher business rates on superstores, hotels, holiday parks and restaurants.

The trade groups estimate that hundreds of sites could close because of the changes, resulting in roughly 120,000 job losses.

Under the proposed overhaul of business rates, which will come into force next April, companies with bigger premises will face an increase in levies to reduce costs for smaller sites.

Labour has argued the reform will be designed to help revive city centres.

This is because the changes are designed to level the playing field between the high street and online giants, with the shake-up hitting large warehouses.

However, retail and hospitality bosses said it risks doing the opposite by forcing so-called large “anchor” stores and entertainment venues to close sites.

Helen Dickinson, the BRC chief executive, urged ministers to hand retailers an exemption from higher business rates to “safeguard hundreds of anchor stores and the vital jobs they sustain”.

Kate Nicholls, the chairman of UKHospitality, said the Chancellor needed to back businesses so they could “develop locations where people want to live, work and invest”.

Tesco and Sainsbury’s bosses warned the Chancellor earlier this year that higher business rates would accelerate the decline of the high street.

In July, Sir Tim Martin, the boss of JD Wetherspoon, said the shake-up would “exacerbate the already ferocious tax disadvantage that pubs are currently labouring under”.

Since then, businesses have come under further pressure as consumers rein in spending ahead of the Budget.

Figures from the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) Distributive Trades Survey revealed retailers sold around 27pc less in the year to October compared to the same period a year earlier.

Martin Sartorius, the principal economist at the CBI, said: “Consumer confidence remains poor, compounded by elevated caution ahead of next month’s Autumn Budget.”

Bosses are understood to have met with Treasury officials in recent weeks, urging them to exempt large retail and hospitality firms from the higher business rates bracket.

One supermarket source said the Government had been warned that the planned changes threatened to drive up food prices, which are already up by almost 5pc in the past year alone.

It comes after retailers were hit with higher costs in last year’s Budget when the Chancellor increased employer National Insurance rates and the minimum wage. New packaging taxes have also put businesses under pressure.

This has led to retailers’ costs rising by £7bn over the past year, according to the BRC.

UKHospitality has also blamed Ms Reeves for hitting the sector with £3.4bn of extra costs.

One supermarket source said they were “hopeful” that Ms Reeves had listened to their concerns and would shelter retailers from higher business rate brackets.

Ms Dickinson said: “Thriving high streets depend on a vibrant mix of outlets – from shops and cafés, to restaurants and entertainment venues. Large retailers are central to this ecosystem, drawing people into town and city centres and boosting footfall for surrounding businesses.

“They provide significant local investment, as well as around one million jobs for people at all stages of their career.”

A Treasury spokesman said: “We’re making business rates fairer by introducing permanently lower rates for retail, hospitality and leisure from April, funded by a higher rate on less than 1pc of the most valuable business properties.

“We’ve also capped corporation tax at 25pc, the lowest in the G7, secured major trade deals with the US, EU and India and seen interest rates cut five times since the election to help businesses across Britain.”

data.title: GSK boss says US is ‘biggest priority’ as Trump pressures drugmakers
data.description:
The boss of Britain’s largest drugmaker has said the US is its “biggest priority” amid pressure from Donald Trump to slash prices for US citizens.

Dame Emma Walmsley, who will step down from GSK at the end of the year, praised the US and said the group is working with the Trump administration after it launched a campaign to address high drug prices.

Shares in pharmaceutical companies surged on Tuesday after rival pharma group Pfizer struck a deal with the White House to lower prices for some of its medicines. Mr Trump has also demanded greater investment in the US from drug companies after introducing a 100pc tariff on branded drugs made abroad.

The Pfizer agreement, which averts tariffs for three years, triggered a relief rally that sent shares in AstraZeneca up 11.2pc, as it reclaimed its place as Britain’s most valuable company. GSK shares jumped by 6.2pc.

Dame Emma admitted GSK was “betting big on the US” after she pledged during Mr Trump’s UK state visit last month to invest $30bn (£22bn) in America over the next five years.

She said: “Absolutely GSK is engaging constructively. The markets also view it this way, as it’s about constructive dialogue between the industry and the Government.

“The US is by far the biggest priority market for our industry because the US is the best country in the world to discover and develop innovation.”

As the country’s largest drugmaker, GSK has become a national champion for the UK pharmaceutical sector, despite generating only a small proportion of its revenues in the UK.

Britain represents just 2pc of the £65bn drugmaker sales, compared to 52pc in the US.

Despite this, Dame Emma said the group would not ditch its listing on the London stock market for New York. GSK’s shares have fallen overall in the eight years since she took over in 2017.

“I’m not getting distracted by the listing questions that everyone keeps asking about,” Dame Emma told Bloomberg’s Women, Money & Power conference.

“Our listing location doesn’t distract from where we allocate our capital in terms of investments. There are no plans for that.”

She also said there had been “zero engagement” on a potential merger with any other UK pharmaceutical company.

AstraZeneca fears

Her comments come days after AstraZeneca stoked fears that Britain’s biggest drugmaker could quit London after it announced plans to list shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

In a shake-up announced on Monday, the FTSE pharmaceuticals giant said it would upgrade its US listing to ensure it is equally as important in New York as it is on the London Stock Exchange.

Bosses said the move would make it easier for the company to raise money from US investors, describing it as “a global listing for global investors in a global company”.

Analysts at AJ Bell said the decision hinted “at the possibility of a more dramatic shift at some point in the future”.

data.title: Volkswagen warns Trump’s tariffs will cost it €5bn a year
data.description:
Volkswagen has fallen to its first quarterly loss since the start of Covid-19 after warning Donald Trump’s tariffs will inflict a €5bn (£4.4bn) a year hit to its business.

The German carmaker, which owns brands including Porsche, Bentley and Audi, on Thursday said it had swung to a €1.3bn loss in the third quarter of 2025, compared to a €2.8bn profit for the same period a year earlier.

It blamed the losses on America’s new trade levies and an abortive shift to electric vehicles (EVs) at Porsche. It warned lower sales to the US will cost the company €5bn in lost revenues each year.

The Wolfsburg-headquartered manufacturer added that it now planned to push ahead with job cuts in its efforts to offset losses from Mr Trump’s trade levies.

Arno Antlitz, Volkswagen’s chief financial officer, said: “Increased trading tariffs and the resulting negative volume effects burden us by up to €5bn on a full-year basis.

“Those effects will continue to persist – and that is why we must rigorously implement the performance programmes in place, push forward efficiency measures and develop new approaches.”

Mr Trump imposed 15pc tariffs on cars imported from the European Union into the US in August. Volkswagen, which is the EU’s biggest carmaker, is heavily exposed as it makes most of its vehicles in Europe.

Sweeping job cuts

Volkswagen, which employs over 650,000 workers worldwide, outlined plans for a sweeping overhaul of its business last year that will see it lay off 35,000 of its German staff over the next five years, in a push to make €4bn in annual savings.

The restructuring plans will see the industrial giant slash production by roughly 700,000 vehicles a year, and move production of its iconic VW Golf from Germany to Mexico.

Meanwhile, Volkswagen recorded a €4.7bn hit from Porsche in the third quarter after the luxury carmaker delayed plans to transition towards mainly selling electric vehicles.

In September, the luxury marque said it would continue producing fossil fuel-powered cars “well into the 2030s”.

Porsche had previously said it expected 80pc of the cars it sold would be battery-powered by 2030. It pinned the change on the slow development of the market for EVs.

The last time Volkswagen posted a quarterly loss was at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic in the second quarter of 2020, when it lost €2.4bn.

The German carmaker also warned that its performance moving forward would depend on securing enough semiconductors, amid uncertainty over crucial supply from Chinese-owned manufacturer Nexperia.

The Dutch government recently took control of a Nexperia factory in the Netherlands over national security concerns, prompting a stand-off with its Chinese owners.

Shares in Volkswagen slipped around 0.9pc in early trade.

data.title: Let teenagers drive buses, ministers told
data.description:
Ministers have been urged to scrap “outdated” restrictions on teenage bus and coach drivers to ease a nationwide staffing shortage.

Bus and coach drivers under 20 are banned from operating services longer than 31 miles, despite qualified 18 and 19-year-olds being permitted to drive articulated lorries or petrol tankers with no distance limit.

Now the Confederation of Passenger Transport (CPT) has called on the Government to “unlock the potential of young people”.

Restrictions on teenage bus and coach drivers exclude them from the vast majority of coach work, as well as many bus routes outside major towns and cities.

The CPT said the limit was hampering recruitment. It stated that the proportion of unfilled coach and bus driver roles in the UK was 12.4 per cent and 3.4 per cent respectively, resulting in a total shortfall of more than 4,000 drivers.

‘I wish I could have started sooner’

Keith McNally, CPT operations director, said: “The evidence is clear: age itself is not a key determinant of collision risk – experience is.

“Department for Transport (DfT) and Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency data show that young vocational drivers have fewer collisions than their peers with car licences, and perform comparably with drivers aged 21 and over.”

Aidan Travasso, who turned 20 earlier this month, became a driver for Swindon-based Barnes Coaches when he was 18 and was disappointed to discover he could not fulfil most of the company’s contracts.

He said: “It didn’t make sense. My driving ability didn’t change between the day before and the day after my 20th birthday.

“Now I can drive longer routes, it’s much more fun. I just wish I could have started sooner.”

The DfT announced in May it will lower the minimum age for train drivers from 20 to 18 to ease staff shortages.

A consultation on a proposal to take similar action for bus and coach drivers was conducted by the Conservative government last year, but no outcome has been published.

‘Remove these outdated restrictions’

The CPT also warned that “many willing applicants drift to other sectors” because they could not start training until they had received their provisional licence, which “often takes weeks or months”.

The body called for this requirement to be dropped.

Graham Vidler, CPT chief executive, said: “We all want safe, reliable and affordable bus and coach services. The quickest way to support that is to unlock the potential of young people who are eager to start their careers in our sector.

“The Government has already taken this step for rail – now it’s time to back Britain’s buses and coaches by removing these outdated restrictions.”

Richard Holden, the shadow transport secretary, said scrapping the 30-mile limit would “open up new opportunities for young drivers, strengthen the coach and bus sectors, and get more services running in rural communities”.

A Department for Transport spokesman said: “Better buses are central to the Government’s Plan for Change, and after decades of decline, we’re providing £1 billion in funding this year to improve the reliability and frequency of bus services across the country through our landmark Bus Services Bill.”

data.title: Shadow banking bubble risks global shock, warns credit rating agency
data.description:
The $3tn (£2.2tn) shadow banking industry has developed “bubble-like characteristics” that could risk triggering a wider global financial shock, the credit ratings agency Fitch has warned.

Fitch said that if a crisis took hold in the private credit market, then it could ripple out to fund managers, banks and insurers who bankroll the market.

The warning, issued this week, adds to a drumbeat of concern after the $12bn collapse of US auto parts giant First Brands was followed by two regional US banks sounding the alarm over bad loans.

This has prompted fears that the incidents could be symptomatic of more serious problems in the market.

Private credit involves companies borrowing from specialist funds, often run by private equity. Compared with traditional bank lending, there is less regulation and transparency.

The market’s size has ballooned 50pc in recent years, and the International Monetary Fund estimates that banks worldwide now have about $4.5tn of exposure to private credit players, not all of which has been drawn down.

Fitch has previously said that the private credit market is still too small to pose a systemic risk to the financial system.

But in its new note, the agency warns that private credit was “emerging from being a niche product for institutional investors to a more significant asset class that is growing not only in scale but complexity”.

This meant that “a financial shock event could reveal unexpected transmission channels” to the wider financial markets. This transmission risk could be exacerbated by “the emergence of traditional ‘bubble-like’ characteristics”.

These included the growing involvement of individual investors alongside big banks and fund managers, and the increased leverage or debt that borrowers were taking on.

Fitch was also seeing more creative ways of packaging the debt, known as “financial innovation”.

Another bubble-like trend was “spread compression”, where investors accept a lower yield on these risky investments, which can signal weaker lending standards.

But Fitch also said it was not yet seeing “classic bubble signs” because investors were still pricing the most high-risk credit more cautiously.

Also, many banks’ exposures to risky borrowers were indirect. The banks also had only “limited liquidity risk”, meaning they would be able, if required, to pull money out of the private credit vehicles.

Fitch also warned, though, that “signs of an economic slowdown in the US are building” could create a risk of more defaults among heavy borrowers in sectors like auto parts and used cars, where private credit user Tricolor Holdings has also filed for bankruptcy.

Fitch said that the US jobs market was “starting to weaken” and “pockets of consumer-related credit performance indicators [are] showing signs of deterioration”.

The Tricolor and First Brands collapses prompted JPMorgan boss Jamie Dimon to warn that more problem-borrowers may be lurking inside the private-credit market.

“My antenna goes up when things like that happen,” he said. “I probably shouldn’t say this, but when you see one cockroach, there’s probably more.”

data.title: Thames Water crisis threatens London super-sewer
data.description:
Thames Water’s debt crisis threatens to trigger millions of pounds in losses for London’s £4.5bn super-sewer.

Tideway Tunnel, which owns the project, has sounded the alarm ahead of a looming handover later this year – with bosses fearing Thames could withhold cash in its scramble to avoid nationalisation.

The sewer owner said it is closely monitoring Thames’s plight and has sought assurances from the Government to ensure the project will not be threatened if the company collapses into special administration.

In its latest annual report, Tideway said: “We continue to note Thames Water’s evolving financial position and this has led to concern that their situation might change.

“There is a possible risk that Thames Water, given its current financial position, or a special administrator may choose not to pay an element of Tideway’s revenue.

“This would not be consistent with Thames Water’s licence and would be expected to lead to a breach and enforcement action.”

As part of its contingency plans, Tideway also considered the possibility of Thames failing to support the sewer’s operations, warning that this “could affect our ability to deliver our investment programme on time and on budget.

“If Thames Water does not comply with the revenue agreement, it could have a financial impact,” the company added.

Concerns over Thames Water’s future come as the company struggles under the weight of a £17bn debt pile.

The company admitted last month that it could enter a taxpayer-backed special administration regime if a rescue deal led by more than 100 creditors fails to succeed.

Thames’s financial crisis is in stark contrast to the completion of Tideway, which has been hailed as a rare infrastructure success story.

The 25km tunnel under the River Thames, which became fully operational earlier this year, represents the biggest improvement to London’s sewage network in 150 years.

Buried 67m deep, the concrete pipe is designed to ease pollution pressures by redirecting sewage away from the river and into a treatment works in east London.

While Thames will not own Tideway, it is expected to be charged an annual fee for its use of the sewer. This will be paid to Bazalgette, a company bankrolled by a group of banks and pension funds.

A Tideway spokesman said: “Tideway is a completely separate, independent company set up to deliver the Thames Tideway Tunnel project.

“This vital new infrastructure is now operational, and has already diverted away nearly eight million tonnes of sewage that would have historically spilled into the Thames.

“We remain confident that Tideway’s revenues are well protected given water industry legislation and the licence obligations that apply to both Thames Water and Tideway. We continue to work effectively with Thames Water to deliver the benefits of the project.”

A Thames spokesman said: “Thames Water collects revenue from customers on Tideway’s behalf and passes it on to Tideway on receipt. Tideway’s revenues are well protected given water industry legislation and the license obligations that apply to both Thames Water and Tideway. We continue to work effectively with Tideway to deliver the benefits of the project.”

data.title: Starmer’s AI drive ‘will lead to hosepipe bans’
data.description:
Sir Keir Starmer’s artificial intelligence (AI) plans risk leading to hosepipe bans and could drive up water bills, a government advisory body has warned.

A report from the Government Digital Sustainability Alliance (GDSA) said that placing major data centres in water-stressed areas could lead to “increased water bills [and] rationing”, adding it risked “potentially exacerbating social conflicts”.

Last week, the Prime Minister trumpeted a series of promised investments in AI data centres, including the construction of Britain’s most powerful AI supercomputer and a new “AI growth zone” in Northumberland.

The string of investments by US tech giants, which coincided with Donald Trump’s state visit, led to predictions of a “big bang” for the British AI industry.

However, the GDSA, a group set up by the Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs, claimed that Britain’s water supplies were not adequately prepared for a boom in data centres, which can require large quantities of water to cool computer systems.

It warned that the tech projects were a “blind spot” in official water forecasting, and that utilities were not planning for a surge in data centre infrastructure.

“The siting of water-intensive infrastructure in already water-stressed areas, particularly those with existing socio-economic vulnerabilities, raises significant environmental justice concerns,” it said.

“This practice could disproportionately impact local communities, potentially leading to increased water bills, rationing or reduced environmental flows.”

It warned there was a conflict between the Government’s AI dreams and Britain’s ability to manage water supplies.

“The rapid expansion of AI presents a profound challenge to the UK’s water security and environmental sustainability,” it said.

“The evidence demonstrates that AI’s substantial water footprint, primarily driven by data centre cooling and energy generation, is escalating at an alarming rate and is largely unaccounted for in current national water resource planning.

“This critical oversight, coupled with existing and projected water deficits in the UK, creates a significant risk of exacerbating water stress, leading to potential social and environmental conflicts.”

Source of conflict

The country is already facing pressure on its future water supply. England will require an extra five billion litres of water a day by 2050, according to the Environment Agency.

The GDSA, which is made up of business executives, academics and industry groups, exists to give the Government advice when developing new policies. Its members views do not necessarily reflect those of the Government.

The report by Chris Kenny, the co-chair of one of the GDSA’s panel groups, said measures recently proposed by water companies to improve Britain’s water supplies by 2050 did not account for the growth in data centres.

Data centres are crucial to AI and use large amounts of energy. Last week, Microsoft pledged to invest £22bn in Britain, the majority of which will go towards new infrastructure.

Thames Water warned that its water supplies risked being stressed by more than 100 new data centres planned in the regions it covers.

The tech industry has disputed that data centres risk adding to Britain’s water problems. Industry body techUK said in a report last month that the majority of new data centres used so-called closed loop-cooling systems that do not require any external water supplies.

Plans to support the AI industry have led to other conflicts within the Government.

Peter Kyle, the Business Secretary, has championed a proposed giant data centre on Teesside that would conflict with a proposed hydrogen plant believed to be supported by Ed Miliband, the Energy Secretary.

A government spokesman said: “Data centres are part of the vital infrastructure behind the digital technology that powers our businesses and everyday lives, and we need substantial investment to harness AI’s transformative potential.

“The planning system takes into account water scarcity and local plans themselves should take into account the long-term implications for water supply. We’re also unlocking £104bn in water infrastructure investment, which includes improving water supplies around data centres.”

data.title: Thames Water lenders prepared to take £7bn hit to avoid nationalisation
data.description:
A group of Thames Water creditors is prepared to effectively write off £7.5bn of debt in a bid to avoid nationalisation.

The consortium has proposed a turnaround plan that would cancel around a third of Thames Water’s near-£20bn debt pile and commit the group to investing in the company.

Outstanding fines would be paid – but the investor group, dubbed London & Valley Water, would also seek leniency on future penalties in exchange for investment.

Thames Water revealed over the summer that annual losses had hit £1.6bn as a soaring debt burden and continued sewage failures fuelled its financial crisis.

Bosses said it would take at least a decade to turn around Britain’s largest water company.

The company’s creditors are looking to secure backing for their plans to avoid the utility being put into a temporary special administration regime, which would effectively wipe out their investments.

Lenders said they would not pay a dividend while conducting their turnaround plans or until the company is listed.

They also committed not to sell the business before the end of March 2030.

The consortium said the “more ambitious” plan would increase investment in Thames Water by around £1bn compared to proposals they submitted to Ofwat in May.

The latest proposal was the result of “three months of detailed discussion” with the water regulator and would “support long-term financial resilience and is intended to help the company pay for outstanding fines”, it added.

Mike McTighe, a City veteran whose current roles include chairman of Telegraph Media Group, would become chairman of Thames Water under the creditors’ proposals.

He said: “There is a huge amount of work to be done to turn around Thames Water and deliver the improved service and environmental outcomes that customers and local communities deserve.

“From day one, we will inject billions in new investment, strengthen Thames Water’s balance sheet, transform the company for thousands of hard-working frontline staff and begin the delivery of an operational turnaround that puts 16 million customers and the environment first.”

Lenders of Thames Water’s “Class A” debt would receive at least 10pc of new equity in the utility company in exchange for writing off about 25pc of their stake, worth around £4bn.

Thames Water said it remains in discussions over the bid but any agreement would be subject to High Court approval.

Chris Weston, the chief executive of Thames Water, said: “Today is an important milestone in our ongoing work with creditors and stakeholders to secure a market-led recapitalisation that establishes the financial and regulatory foundations required to support the investment and performance improvements our customers expect.”

data.title: The soaring cost of mince signals we’re in for a difficult winter
data.description:
How much is a packet of mince? That’s not a trick question. Fry some onions, garlic, maybe some carrots and celery, brown the mince, then add a tin of tomatoes, maybe a splash of milk (“lends a desirable sweetness” according to my favourite Marcella Hazan ragu recipe), leave to bubble away on the hob and then serve with pasta, and you used to have a budget meal for a family of four.

Those were the days. I have been following a guy on X who is posting a weekly “mince watch”, although prices seem to be going up by the hour. It feels like the hyper-inflationary Weimar Republic. Not long, Marjorie, before we’re wheeling a barrow full of tenners to Aldi to purchase a punnet of blueberries.

Everywhere I go, people are complaining about food costs. “Minced beef now over £5 for 500g. Ridiculous.”

“What the heck just happened to the price of mince?” demands another shopper next to a picture of Asda lean mince at £8.32.

The latest shock update: “£9.50 for 500g of mince in Sainsbury’s. Plus security tag, that says it all really.” While inspecting the mince in Waitrose, I notice that no one is buying steak; the shelves are full. If the Waitrose classes are tightening their belts, things must be bad.

Whatever the Consumer Price Index (CPI) may say, food inflation is not running at 3.8 per cent or 4.9 per cent or even 5.1 per cent. (Is someone massaging the figures to hide the full dreadful picture from the consumer?) It feels like we are in the middle of the worst cost of living crisis I can remember, but there is hardly a peep about it on the news.

There will be a lot in that position this winter, I fear. “I use exactly the same shopping list every four weeks (pension day),” one reader wrote. “I did my shopping yesterday and it cost £190. Four weeks ago exactly the same items cost me £120. Government figures on inflation are a complete nonsense.” Yes, they are.

“Prices are mad!” says another Telegraph subscriber. “I can do a weekly shop using a small trolley, used to cost me about £70 max, now it’s around £100. I buy very similar every week, no booze or cleaning products, just food. Will fill three bags for life, you don’t get much for your money. The supermarkets have been continually raising their prices since Labour took power. Everyone can see and feel the pain of it.”

Pole-vault price jumps are common. Items no longer go up by a couple of pence. A meal deal can leap 23p over a weekend. (How is that justified?) Your favourite salted butter is a quarter more expensive. HOW MUCH?

Pop into the supermarket for a few bits and suddenly it’s 60 quid. “Have I put a bottle of champagne in there by mistake?” I ask my favourite check-out lady. “I know, it’s scary,” she sighs. “Everyone is really worried.” I notice people are removing items from their baskets and abandoning them, presumably in shock.

A pensioner admits that she and her husband have almost stopped buying protein – far too expensive – and are subsisting on soup and toast. She wonders if they will be able to stay healthy. “I may have to start shoplifting; everyone else does,” jokes Clara. At least I think she’s joking. Clara is 87.

Actually, an octogenarian shoplifting gang cruising the aisles on mobility scooters and using sticks to knock items off the shelves might shame the four big supermarkets who are making record profits while their customers hear the pips squeak. Only pressure from Aldi and Lidl is forcing them to keep prices within reason, and some people claim even Lidl has got pricey.

What on earth is going on? I blame the useless Labour Government – who doesn’t? Chancellor Rachel Reeves promised to “put more money in your pocket” but the wretched woman’s calamitous, economically innumerate Budget last year only drove up expenses. It’s definitely not the farmers’ fault. “I get the same price for my lamb as I did eight years ago,” moans one.

It looks like the vertiginous rise in consumer food and catering prices since summer 2024 is a result of the supermarkets passing on the rise in employers’ National Insurance contributions and minimum wage increases introduced by Labour. (So much for Rachel from Accounts not taxing “working people”, the dim mare.)

The new packaging tax (EPR), designed to end our throwaway society, is also significantly adding to food inflation, pushing up the cost of everything from sausages to soft drinks. The British Retail Consortium (BRC) expects more than 80 per cent of the EPR’s cost to be passed on to the luckless consumer. Thanks a lot.

“It’s about 3p on a pack of sausages,” says Andrew Keeble, the co-founder of Heck. This year’s packaging-tax bill for the family-run food manufacturer, based near Bedale, North Yorkshire, is £153,000. Like other food companies, Heck has already absorbed the increases in National Insurance and the “national living wage”, but Keeble suggests this new tax will have to be “passed on to a fairly cash-strapped nation”.

Green initiatives in general are costing us horribly dear. Ed Miliband’s net zero zealotry and windmill lunacy have given the UK pretty much the highest manufacturing electricity prices in the developed world – food manufacturers pass on those costs.

My friend Karen, who runs the wonderful deli and grocers in our town, explains how everything that goes into producing a jar of strawberry jam – from picking the fruit to making the glass jar – has soared in price. “Customers wonder why we’ve jacked up the prices, but we’re not making any more money. Quite the contrary; like any shop still left open, we’re just about hanging in there.”

If the Chancellor raises the minimum wage again in her upcoming Budget – a suicidal display of fake socialist magnanimity – God help us, we’ll all be grubbing for roots and making soup out of bird seed. The family of four goldfinches that are dependent on me feeding them are one of my biggest outgoings, and I can’t abandon the little beauties in the winter.

How are you finding the cost of food? Have you cut back? Let me know. Don’t, er, mince your words.

data.title: Thames Water’s rescue plan risks setting a dangerous precedent
data.description:
The latest version of a creditor-led rescue plan for Thames Water ticks multiple boxes. One can see why the company, ministers and the industry regulator might be minded to give it the green light in the coming weeks.

The pressure to hammer out a deal is intense. The threat of a multibillion-pound bill landing on Rachel Reeves’s desk before her Budget in November is concentrating Whitehall minds.

Thames is burning cash rapidly. A separate announcement from the company revealed that in August it called on the remaining £628m of a £1.5bn emergency loan.

It is further worrying evidence of the extent to which an organisation providing critical services to 13 million people continues to live hand-to-mouth after years of reckless ownership.

With the clock ticking, the “London and Valley” consortium of lenders has come up with a decent upgrade on the somewhat vague proposal published a month ago.

Then, the prospective new owners declared their undying commitment to “a new transparent and collaborative relationship with regulators”, before outlining a plan lacking in details.

The highlights of their latest attempt include a more generous portion of equity and a bigger debt write-off than previously envisaged. A commitment to not pay dividends for five years, along with the ambition of eventually returning Thames to the stock market are also welcome measures.

Yet all the hard work that has gone into answering many of the concerns of regulators, Government and long-suffering customers risks being overshadowed by what amounts to a fresh attempt to wriggle out of fines.

Having sensibly given up on trying to dodge outstanding penalties for pumping sewage into waterways, Thames’s wannabe owners are now trying to inoculate themselves against future punishment.

“The current regulatory framework for the water industry does not allow it to successfully turnaround its business,” London and Valley says.

The consortium won’t take “no” for an answer, it seems.

Steve Reed, the former environment secretary, told parliament in June that Thames must meet its statutory obligations, after being asked about possible “regulatory easements”.

But the very idea that an industry that treats Britain’s rivers as its dumping ground should face softer environmental targets – or “stretching but achievable incentives” in the consortium’s words – won’t wash.

It’s hard to square this with the consortium’s warm words.

Mike McTighe, the proposed future chairman of Thames – he is also chairman of the company behind The Telegraph – talks about “rebuilding public trust”.

The creditors themselves admit that Thames has presided over “a cycle of underinvestment and underperformance that has driven trust in Thames Water to an all-time low.”

Few would argue with that assessment. Yet any agreement that makes it easier for the company to pollute with greater impunity is an improbable basis for the restoration of Thames’s relationship with the public.

Consider that in an industry that has vandalised the environment, this is a chronic offender.

Thames’s record is getting worse, not better. Some 50pc more raw sewage was discharged into Britain’s waterways from Thames’s ageing system last year, compared with the previous 12 months.

In May, Thames Water was fined £123m by Ofwat – the biggest ever fine imposed by the regulator.

From a purely financial perspective, the creditors’ plea for clemency is understandable.

They expect future fines of more than £1bn if current regulations are applied and argue that something has to give if Thames is to receive the investment it needs.

This financial hole was of Thames’s own making, however. Its creditors bankrolled it as it hollowed itself out. To turn around now and demand that the rules are changed to make pumping effluent into rivers a less costly business is an affront to justice and risks setting a horrible precedent.

Perhaps even now, after months and months of negotiations, the hedge funds that swooped in to buy up debt on the cheap when Thames was on the brink, still don’t understand the extent of public and political anger.

Customer ire stretches to the whole gamut of misdeeds – rising bills, poor service, undeserved dividends and excessive executive pay.

But it is the epidemic of pollution that has attracted the most fury. That the creditors have chosen to attack on that front seems “courageous”, as they say in the Civil Service.

Indeed, I am willing to bet that the majority of people want to see stiffer fines, not softer ones, particularly if the current set-up has failed to act as a deterrent. Weaker rules would surely lead to more pollution, not less.

Meanwhile, the knock-on effect of granting Thames an easier ride would be that every other water company in Britain would be entitled to expect the same exemptions on the basis of fairness.

A reminder from the creditors that their offer is the only credible one left after private equity firm KKR abandoned its bid looks designed to focus minds. Ditto talks of how the plan “will avoid special administration”, and ensure that “Thames Water’s turnaround will not fall to the UK taxpayer”.

Decency, however, demands that Ofwat and the Government don’t allow themselves to be pushed around by a bunch of opportunistic hedge funds.

data.title: My first UK holiday in years showed me what our country has lost
data.description:
I recently visited Britain – a bit in England but mainly Wales – for the first time in quite a while.

Having lived in France as The Telegraph’s France destination expert for many years I had a smashing time, thank you. The rain barely bothered me.

This was Wales. What did I expect? Sunstroke? Anyway, the principality looks good, and richly green, in the rain. And there were plenty of pubs in which to dry out. Externally, I mean.

Along the way, though, I noticed a few things which I’d either forgotten about, hadn’t noticed before or had cropped up since my last visit.

Among them were, in no particular order:

The demise of tourist information centres

Turn up in even quite big towns – Carmarthen, Swansea – ask for the tourist office and people look blank.

“It’s all online now,” a council fellow told me. “People look it up before they leave home.”

Not everyone. Not me. For a start, before you leave home, you don’t necessarily know everywhere you’re going to be visiting. And when you get there, do you really want to scroll through the infinite reams of hysterical promo material which constitute most official tourism websites?

Wouldn’t you rather talk to a real person who may address your particular interest without your having to wade through disquisitions on zip lining and activities for single mothers with school-age children?

Or, to put it another way, every town in France has a tourist office, as do many villages, and theirs is the planet’s most visited country. Could it be that this is one thing that the French have got right?

We seem to have lost all our family-run restaurants

Every French town has an abundance. Where are they in Britain? Don’t get me wrong. We ate well – but in pubs and chain restaurants.

The establishments where husband cooks and wife serves (or vice versa) cram by the score into city-centre streets in France. Although we looked, we found precisely none in our 11 days in the UK.

The health-and-safety obsession has gone into overdrive

“Welcome. Table for two? Any allergies?” This rang out upon arrival at nearly every restaurant we visited. It may be linked to a sense that Britain spends much of its time protecting everyone against, well, everything.

As if the average Briton were rather daft. (By a breakfast room toaster: “Warning: may get hot”; at traffic lights: “Stop at red light”.)

This assumption that Britons lack both gumption and resilience seemed new to me. Then again, given the epidemic of mobility scooters on city streets – I saw more in a week in the UK than in a decade in France – the question perhaps requires further research.

Nobody stays out late

Spending happy moments in a good restaurant which, last time I looked around, was humming with diners. Now it’s 8.45pm, I look around again, and everyone’s gone. Our noisy little party is all that’s left.

Waiters and waitresses are smiling but clearly hanging about, waiting for us to leave. This happened often. Was nightlife always this way? Have all those people really gone home? At this hour?

How do Spanish visitors cope with having to eat dinner before they’ve finished lunch?

Public transport is actually pretty good

“We’re going to travel by train and bus,” I said. “Ha! Good luck with that,” replied a wiseacre British friend. But over 11 days, public transport worked terrifically – frequent, reliable, operated by drivers, especially in Wales, who had clearly taken vows of helpfulness. It got us into small towns and villages which, were they in France, wouldn’t have seen a bus unless that bus were lost.

It meant we got to appreciate the landscape without having to navigate or negotiate a way through, and faced no parking problems. Plus public transport favours encounters.

Such as the three well-dressed young women who polished off two bottles of Prosecco on the mid-morning train from Manchester Piccadilly to Chester. Thus did they tee themselves up nicely for a day at the races. “Talkative” didn’t do them justice.

Slovenly speech has become an epidemic

I do wish that the language fairy might move among my fellow citizens and restore the letter “T” to its proper place (so “lighting”, not “li’ing”; “little”, not “li’el”; “better”, not “beh’er”), and banish entirely “Know what I mean?”, “No worries”, “Enjoy”, and “Mate”. She might also rid us of split infinitives and misuse of words such as “hopefully” and “decimate”.

I bumped into all these in spoken or written English during the stay – though, oddly, less so in Wales. It is, perhaps, more difficult to speak badly with a Welsh lilt. Most of all, I’d like the fairy to disabuse us of the notion that speaking properly is a snobbish affectation.

It isn’t. In France, second-division football players usually express themselves as if they were deputy headmasters. Like everyone else in the country, they wish to be taken for clever, not stupid.

The pubs are a mixed bag

Wetherspoons, 4pm, Tuesday afternoon, Carmarthen – the enormous place is heaving. Heaving. I can barely hear my wife say: “Do we have to stay?” Who are the dozens drinking through the afternoon on a Tuesday?

Might this explain the mobility scooters? Wetherspoons obviously does a fantastic job, but this is not the image I have when, from a foreign field, I imagine a British pub.

Fortunately, the Plume of Feathers (“Wales’s smallest pub” – about the size of our lounge) is nearby, with its memories of Richard Burton and Ray Gravell.

Swansea’s No Sign bar – venerable outpost of wood, wine, Welsh whiskey and warmth amid the mini-Vegas of Swansea’s Wind Street – also fulfils a proper pub function. It lays on a Wednesday night quiz. We took part. I wish to say no more on the subject.

There are street signs everywhere, but not the ones you need

Amid the frenzy of signs clogging up Britain, the only ones you actually need – telling you where you are in any given town or city – are very often AWOL.

Please replace them. Some people really do want to find their way around Swansea.

The Welsh have mastered hymn-singing

Gosh, the Welsh have it nailed. Choral singing, too. Given the limp murmuring of much church singing in France, I’d forgotten just how sense-smacking a choir can be.

Listen to the Côr Godre’r Aran and, were you on the cusp of faith, this might tip you over.

But we’re still a friendly bunch

Everywhere – pubs, buses, restaurants, shops, hotels, cafés – we encountered real smiles, real conversation, real eagerness to be pleasant and helpful.

Easily sufficient to overlook the “Any allergies?” nonsense. I’d forgotten just how jolly, informally, agreeably friendly Britain could be.

data.title: ‘Queens of Soho’ bank £23m from West End property empire
data.description:
The multimillionaire granddaughters of the late Soho porn baron Paul Raymond have banked £23m from their West End property empire.

Soho Estates, which owns much of the area, paid out the sum in dividends to Fawn James, 39, and India Rose James, 33, according to recently filed accounts.

The sisters inherited Soho Estates from Mr Raymond, the self-made millionaire dubbed the “King of Soho” after he died in 2008. Their mother Debbie died of a heroin overdose aged just 36.

data.title: Labour cuts electricity charges for factories after wave of closures
data.description:

“There are of course other energy demands in the sector, in the economy. I’m looking really closely at that, and I’ll be making other announcements in the not too distant future.”

He also hinted that the Government would press ahead with its deregulation drive and pledged to “get the balance right” on an employment rights bill that businesses and Left-leaning think tanks have warned will damage growth and the economy.

Speaking after the Lords voted through several amendments related to day one rights and increasing the powers of the unions, Mr Kyle said: “There will be 27 consultations that will be launched by my department. He also suggested that the Government would go further and faster in its deregulation drive as the government dashes for growth.

“There will be more announcements to come into the future when it comes to energy, but … we’re going to carry on with the same kind of zeal and urgency into the future, on planning reform, on regulatory reform, and these targeted bits of support.”

Businesses tentatively welcomed the energy’s announcement.

data.title: BlackRock loses $500m on shadow banking blow-up
data.description:
The world’s biggest investment group is facing a $500m (£380m) hit after its shadow banking business fell victim to an alleged fraud.

BlackRock’s private credit investment arm, HPS Investment Partners, has started legal action to recover loans it made to a US telecom firm, which has been accused of faking payments from customers.

The loss will fuel concerns about the opaque shadow banking industry, which has drawn billions of pounds of investment from major City institutions but is now teetering on the brink of crisis.

BlackRock’s case is centred on an alleged fraud relating to loans HPS provided to Bankim Brahmbhatt, the owner of US based telecoms firms Broadband Telecom and Bridgevoice.

HPS lent the money on the condition that Mr Brahmbhatt pledge millions of dollars owed by customers as collateral for the loan.

However, BlackRock claims that when it tried to verify these receivables, the scheme unravelled, with funds from the loans instead diverted offshore.

The US funds giant alleges that Mr Brahmbhatt and his companies had forged contracts, emails and invoices to make it seem as though this money was owed by established telecoms companies.

BNP Paribas is also said to have helped BlackRock to finance the loans to Mr Brahmbhatt and his companies.

Alter Domus, a financial services firm acting for HPS, filed the lawsuit in August.

A number of companies linked to Mr Brahmbhatt, including New York-based invoice financing firm Carriox Capital, have since filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the US.

Mr Brahmbhatt denies allegations of fraud, according to the Wall Street Journal, which first reported the legal battle.

The recent collapses of US car parts maker First Brands and subprime car lender Tricolor amid allegations of fraud triggered a stock market rout this month as traders became spooked about potential bad loans.

US banks have $4.5tn of exposure to loans from financial institutions outside the banking sector, sparking fears of a hidden crisis that could lead to another financial crash.

The IMF has sounded the alarm about the potential fallout from the unregulated private credit market, while JP Morgan boss Jamie Dimon has warned about the emergence of more “cockroaches” hiding in the financial system.

BlackRock, Mr Brahmbhatt and BNP Paribas were contacted for comment.

data.title: HSBC on alert over fears of shadow banking crisis
data.description:
HSBC has said it is on alert for a possible shadow banking crisis as concerns about the private credit industry grow.

Pam Kaur, HSBC’s chief financial officer, said on Tuesday that the bank had relatively small exposure to the private loans industry but was concerned about the “second and the third order risk” if issues start to affect the industry more broadly.

She said: “The thing that worries me most, and I have gone through crises as a chief risk officer before, is the second and the third order risk you have from your counterparties who may be impacted by a situation... so that’s what we monitor very closely.”

Ms Kaur added it was difficult to monitor the potential risks it faces from any possible meltdowns in the shadow banking industry, given much of the risk was indirect.

Concern has spread since the collapses of US car parts manufacturer First Brands, and Tricolor, an American subprime car loan lender. Both failed with little warning and were heavily reliant on private credit, a corner of finance often referred to as shadow banking.

This form of finance involves private equity and other non-bank lenders extending credit to companies.

Concerns have been raised about the lack of transparency in the $3tn (£2.2tn) market and the possibility of lax lending standards.

This has fuelled fears that more collapses could be imminent. Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JP Morgan, said: “When you see one cockroach, there are probably more.” JP Morgan itself recorded a $170m loss from its exposure to Tricolor.

The Bank for International Settlements – often called the central bank for central banks – warned this week that the life insurance industry may be riven with hidden risks as a result of its mounting exposures to private credit.

It warned that “many of these investments are more obscure, with information hardly obtainable in common data sources” compared to publicly traded debt.

Insurers backed by private equity have become particularly keen on “private letters”, a form of ratings which cannot be cross-checked by regulators or other analysts, the BIS warned.

“Private ratings are not publicly disclosed, which prevents external validation and facilitates rating shopping. These ratings are concentrated among smaller rating agencies, which may face commercial incentives to assign more favourable ratings,” it said.

“This opacity can lead to inflated assessments of creditworthiness and, correspondingly, undercapitalised exposures.”

Goldman Sachs: No sign it’s systemic

David Solomon, Goldman Sachs’ chief executive, downplayed fears of a systemic shadow banking crisis on Tuesday.

Mr Solomon, who has led the investment bank since 2018, said the recent bankruptcies of First Brands and Tricolor were “idiosyncratic events” rather than signs of a larger crisis.

In an interview with Bloomberg TV, Mr Solomon said: “I don’t see anything in the context of a handful of bad credit situations that’s leading me to say we have a systemic issue around the corner.”

He added that while an economic shock could lead to more losses on other private debt deals, “that’s different than a systemic crisis”.

HSBC and Goldman Sachs both had no direct exposure to either First Brands or Tricolor.

Ms Kaur’s comments came as HSBC reported a 14pc drop in its pre-tax profits to $7.3bn after recording a $1.1bn hit linked to Bernie Madoff’s ponzi scheme.

Herald Fund SPC, a hedge fund that was a victim of Mr Madoff’s scam, filed a lawsuit against HSBC’s Luxembourg unit in relation to the investment in 2009, before a local court rules in its favour this week. HSBC has said it will appeal the ruling.

data.title: Millions of households to face higher water bills
data.description:
Millions of households are facing higher-than-expected water bills after the competition watchdog allowed five utility companies to increase their charges.

Following a provisional ruling by the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), Anglian Water, Northumbrian Water, South East Water, Southern Water and Wessex Water will be able to increase bills by a collective £556m over the next five years.

While that is less than the £2.7bn requested by the companies, it will still lead to some households paying annual bills of up to £638 a year.

Emma Hardy, the minister for water and flooding, said she understood the public’s anger over bill rises, but expected companies to offer support to those struggling to pay.

Between them, Anglian and Northumbrian have been allowed to raise bills by a further 1pc, while Southern, South East and Wessex have been handed increases of 3pc, 4pc and 5pc, respectively.

Together, they serve around seven million customers across the UK.

The ruling means that Anglian will charge an average bill of £599, while Northumbrian bill payers will pay £495. South East Water will increase bills to £322, while Southern will charge £638.

Wessex was handed the biggest increase of 5pc, meaning its bills will rise to £622. All had asked for larger increases.

Appeal to the CMA

It comes after the companies appealed to the CMA earlier this year, requesting permission to increase their bills higher than Ofwat, the water regulator, had previously ruled.

In defence of its decision, the CMA said the extra money would help reduce pollution and strengthen supply, although it also said it would help cover the companies’ rising debt costs.

Kirstin Baker, who chaired an independent group of experts appointed by the CMA, said: “We’ve found that water companies’ requests for significant bill increases, on top of those allowed by Ofwat, are largely unjustified.

“We understand the real pressure on household budgets and have worked to keep increases to a minimum, while still ensuring there is funding to deliver essential improvements at a reasonable cost.”

Thames Water, Britain’s biggest water company, had also appealed, but its proceedings have been put on hold while it battles to stave off nationalisation.

Ms Hardy said efforts were being made to restore the public’s trust in water companies.

She said: “We’ve made sure that investment cash goes into infrastructure upgrades, not bonuses, and we’re creating a tough new regulator to clean up our waterways and restore trust in the system.”

It comes amid growing anger over the state of the water sector, which has been responsible for a rise in sewage failures in recent years.

Mike Keil, the chief executive of the Consumer Council for Water (CCW), said: “Many customers are still trying to absorb the impact of April’s unprecedented rise in water bills, so any further increases will be very unwelcome.

“CCW’s own analysis suggests there was an opportunity to reduce these five companies’ financing costs, cutting bills by around £41 a year, but instead the CMA has chosen to increase their rate of return.

“There is a danger the customers of these companies will end up paying more, without seeing any additional improvements in return.”

Joanna Elson, the chief executive of Independent Age, a charity, said higher bills would be “extremely damaging to people on low incomes living in these areas”.

She said: “The people in later life we support tell us the drastic lengths they are taking to reduce their water costs, including only washing a couple of times a week, not flushing the toilet and cutting down on laundry. This shouldn’t be happening in modern Britain.”

Ms Elson added: “We urge the UK Government to protect customers on low incomes from rising water bills by establishing a national water social tariff. This will end the postcode lottery.

 “It’s not right that your address dictates how much financial support you receive.”
