data.title: The little-known quango choking off Britain’s housebuilding
data.description:
Britain is not building homes quickly enough. Housebuilding has fallen to the lowest level in almost a decade, and the number of housing starts dropped by 26pc between July and September compared to the previous three-month period, according to industry analyst Glenigan.

The picture is especially dire in the capital. “It’s disastrous. The number of new starts in London has fallen by over 70pc in the past year. Only 4,170 homes were started during the last financial year,” says Ben Hopkinson, of the Centre for Policy Studies think tank. “A huge reason for that is the Building Safety Regulator.”

The BSR was established in 2022, in the wake of the Grenfell Tower disaster to raise safety standards across all buildings, setting out rules for their construction and design. The strictest rules apply to residential blocks over 18m or with seven or more storeys. These buildings must go through a new three-stage approval process overseen by the regulator before, during and after construction.

While well-meaning, the BSR is holding back construction of essential new homes, as well as hampering development of existing ones.

Renovations and home improvements in such buildings can fall under the scope of the BSR. While simple repairs are exempt, more significant renovations in homes located in blocks over seven storeys or 18m, such as moving a fire door, altering plumbing or knocking down a wall, require the BSR’s approval before contractors can start work.

Between October 2023 and March 2025, over two thirds of pre-construction applications were rejected by the BSR. Of the 193 new-build high-risk building applications lodged since the foundation of the BSR, just 15 have successfully cleared the approval process.

The regulator has also become notorious within the industry for lengthy delays; the average approval waiting time on new-build projects has grown to 36 weeks, three times longer than the BSR’s original target.

“Literally tens of thousands of homes, as well as major commercial developments, are stuck in the quango, which is causing a chilling effect across the industry,” says Sam Bensted, of the British Property Federation (BPF). “Developers [are battling] wider viability issues and don’t want to risk being stuck in the system for up to year, instead of the supposed 12-week maximum.”

‘The BSR poses an existential threat’

Constant delays and long approval times have had dire ramifications for the construction industry and property developers, which are struggling to plan projects and deliver them on time.

Dominic Curran, also of the BPF, says: “It’s among the top factors, if not the most significant, behind the lack of new homes. It’s being described by one of our members – a major developer – as existential to the survival of their business.”

The BSR’s rules not only affect new construction; renovations to homes in buildings that fall under the regulator’s criteria can also require approval.

Sarah, 55* – who does not want to use her real name as she is still dealing with the regulator – bought a flat with her partner last year in central London. Despite being an older building with no cladding, its height means that making renovations to the property inside must be approved by the BSR.

While Sarah is not knocking down any walls, the scale of the renovation of her kitchen and bathroom, which includes moving a fire door, means she requires approval from the regulator.

For Sarah and her family, what was meant to be a straightforward job has escalated into a Kafkaesque nightmare. Work was meant to start months ago, but a series of lengthy delays by the BSR has meant that it is still not under way.

“The deadline comes and goes with no communication at all. The initial deadline was in May; they asked for an extension for four weeks. Then in June they asked for an extension for six more weeks.

“They say that if they don’t agree to the extension, your project is dropped and you’re denied permission. Then there’s no comeback unless you go to the Secretary of State.”

Sarah has had to pay almost £5,000 in application fees, and has been exasperated by the slow progress.

“Kitchen and bathroom suppliers, various contractors… everybody is just waiting. You can’t help but think about all the business that is just not happening because of this. There is no reason to buy a flat in a building over six storeys.

“When we submitted our application, people didn’t realise how big the delays would be, and the expense that can be added to buying one of these flats. When you think about the amount of housing stock you’re talking about across the country, it’s madness.”

‘No incentive to approve anything’

The Government, aware of the problem posed by the BSR and the fact that it is blocking development, is set to introduce a fast-track process for new-build applications, as well as move the regulator from under the Health and Safety Executive to the Ministry for Housing and Local Government. But this will do little to fix the problem, warns Hopkinson.

“It’s a solution that has zero incentive to approve anything. In cases [such as Sarah’s], the BSR will continually ask for an extension with the implicit threat that if you don’t give it, they will just reject the application, while asking for more and more money. That sounds like an institution that won’t be suddenly and easily reformed to approve lots more homes and refurbishments.”

Unless the Government acts, the country is unlikely to see the number of new homes it desperately needs to help more first-time buyers on to the property ladder. Hopkinson advocates for a stripping-back of the BSR’s purview to stimulate development and refurbishment.

“They could avoid flat refurbishment cases, and only focus on areas where cladding is a real issue. Or they could have a rule of ‘positive silence’ – if they don’t respond to you within an allotted time it’s assumed that they’ve approved it,” he says.

A BSR spokesman said: “This regulatory process is new and there are issues causing frustrations for both industry and the regulator. We are working together to resolve these. There should be no tension between building high volumes of homes and ensuring safety.”

A Ministry for Housing spokesman said: “We have brought new leadership to the Building Safety Regulator who have immediately focused on speeding up decision making on building control approval.

“We know more needs to be done which is why we are going further with a ‘building acceleration package’ to get Britain building, including overhauling the BSR’s performance.

“This will reduce unnecessary delays without compromising safety so we can build 1.5 million homes.”

data.title: London buses ‘infested with cockroaches’
data.description:
London buses are infested with cockroaches, drivers have claimed.

Cockroaches have been spotted aboard dozens of Transport for London (TfL) buses and in drivers’ rest areas, prompting safety campaigners to described the situation as “untenable”.

Transport bosses have launched an investigation after London bus safety campaigners raised the issue in a letter, more than a year after The Telegraph first revealed the scale of the problem.

Passengers have also noticed the infestation. This week, Matilda O’Flaherty, a 21-year-old student, told The Telegraph she had seen two cockroaches during a journey on a number 17 bus in August.

Describing how one had emerged from a hole in the seat before crawling up her leg, she said: “It was so gross, and it was about the size of my thumb.”

One driver on route 159 told the London Bus Forums group he had found a cockroach in his drink. In a video recorded inside the vehicle, he said: “I went to take a sip from my drink and felt something in my mouth. I spat it out and saw it was a cockroach. I felt sick and ended up vomiting.”

Elsewhere, the group named buses on routes 159, 345 and 55 as suffering infestations.

Kevin Mustafa, a London bus safety campaigner, said it was more than an “occasional nuisance”, with “many drivers describing infestations”.

He told the BBC on Monday: “The current state is untenable for drivers who already face demanding working conditions. London bus drivers are reporting persistent issues with cockroaches and unsanitary conditions onboard their vehicles.

“This is not a matter of occasional nuisance. Many drivers describe infestations, and the situation is starting to pose real health, safety and well-being risks.”

Cockroaches are typically associated with unhygienic environments, although earlier this year the insects were also reported to be plaguing NHS hospitals earlier this year.

Last year, Mr Mustafa, claimed TfL’s contracted bus operators were “not cleaning the buses properly” and that “at least once a week” he heard a report of insects aboard a vehicle.

A TfL spokesman said instances of cockroaches being reported aboard buses were “rare”, adding: “We are committed to working together with operators to provide a clean environment for staff and customers.

“All buses are also cleaned every night before entering service and reports such as these are rare. We take any report seriously, and are urgently investigating the specific incidents that have been raised.

“As with any reports, we will take appropriate action as part of the investigation, which can include taking buses out of service for inspection, deep cleans and treatment with specialist equipment if necessary.

“We would like to reassure staff that our operators would never take action against people raising concerns about welfare or safety and encourage any driver with concerns to contact their employer, their union, or contact us directly.”

data.title: Is this really the time for segregated trains?
data.description:
With Islamic extremism on the rise in the UK - is now really the time to be segregating the sexes on trains?

There were rightly howls of outrage when women were banned from taking part in a fun run across Tower Hamlets earlier this month.

The 5km Muslim Charity Run in Victoria Park, East London, was billed as “inclusive” and “family-friendly” even though organisers at the East London Mosque forbade any female over 12 from joining in.

This seemingly obvious act of sexual discrimination is currently being investigated under the Equalities Act.

Now there’s a call for women-only carriages on trains that would surely play into the hands of those who advocate keeping men and women apart. 

A petition is gaining momentum after 21-year-old student activist Camille Brown called for at least one women-only carriage on all Tube trains after experiencing sexual harassment on the London Underground.

While it’s true that reported sexual offences have risen year on year by more than 10 per cent on Tubes, trains and buses across the capital, this isn’t the way to deal with it.

If women don’t feel safe on public transport then the solution is to criminalise the offenders – not segregate their victims. 

This would do nothing to tackle the root cause of harassment and misogynistic behaviour but instead shift the responsibility from perpetrators to the women they prey on. It also runs the risk of emboldening perverts by forcing women into designated “safe zones”. 

Countries like Japan and India have women-only carriages but reports suggest harassment hasn’t disappeared, it’s just been displaced.

True equality surely means women (and men) being able to move freely and safely in public? 

We all want to protect single sex spaces, but we shouldn’t be actively turning unisex public spaces into men-free zones. It’s not just defeatist but downright discriminatory.

data.title: To restore Britain, start with the rail dining car
data.description:
Among stiff competition, few experiences more totally obliterate any lingering faith in Britain today than the average train journey. Penned like cattle into stiff plastic seats, stifled by delays and cancellations, bombarded by youths playing music out loud and preyed upon by conductors yearning to triple charge you for what you thought was the right ticket, the average railway journey is an express train into misery.

Yet amid this litany of woe, there is the worst offender. I’ve had some depressing meals in my time, from school dinner slop to peculiar post-club kebabs. But no culinary catastrophe comes close to the miserable pickings offered by your average rail buffet car. Remembering that half of what is mislabelled a menu is missing at any one time, one is usually offered a bleak selection of stale sandwiches, tepid bacon rolls, unimaginative crisps and depressing paninis. Before boarding a long-distance train today, I always make a packed lunch.

I wasn’t always so dour. I was a train-mad tot, raised between Thomas the Tank Engine, toy tracks and weekend Tube trips. As I grew older, I wept over pictures of disused stations, put railway posters up with my Margaret Thatcher and Jenna Coleman portraits, and re-watched John Betjeman’s Metro-Land with a fanaticism that would put many a jihadi to shame. But the fantasy has died as my professional obligations have made train travel a daily dread.

It shouldn’t have to be like this. We did once know how to make the experience enjoyable. Travelling by rail through Britain should be joyous. Even if one has to stop off at a crime against architecture grotesquely mislabelled as a station, one yearns to see our country’s magnificence while hurtling between destinations in far greater comfort than a motorway slog. An obvious ground zero for rail restorationism is the dining car.

Anyone who has seen North by Northwest or From Russia with Love can attest to the inherent charm of an old-fashioned dining car. Who wouldn’t want a long-distance railway journey enhanced by tucking in to a three-course meal with a decent claret or three? Who wouldn’t rather enjoy a cocktail as the country passes by than a lukewarm lager or oddly frosty coffee? Luxury train journeys with dining experiences – like the Northern Belle, branded “Britain’s poshest train”, and available for booking for Christmas dinner – are doing great business. Why not bring this back to the masses?

There is a 150-odd year tradition of doing so. The Pullman dining car is synonymous with luxury. Originally built by the Pullman Company for dining, sleeping and lounge use, the term still applies to a few remaining high-end train dining services. But the number of them has shrunk precipitously. When the railways were privatised in 1995 almost 250 trains a day offered a dining car. Within two decades, that had shrunk to only four. Privatisation saw passenger numbers double and investment increase nine-old, but at the cost of making journeys soulless.

With Labour’s renationalisation push, there is a chance for a reset. Yet the first returns of renewed state-control are predictably unpromising, with delays and cancellations on South Western Railway rising by 50 per cent since nationalisation. Labour’s technocrats lack the vision required to restore our railways. Which is why the cause of the dining car should be taken up by a politician with a far better appreciation of a long lunch’s merits: Nigel Farage.

The Reform leader may prefer private helicopter to rail. But with his newfound penchant for nationalisation, Farage is already fishing in this pool. What could be more appropriate than pledging to put a Boisdale’s on every inter-city service? Back in 2010, Ukip pledged to “make the Circle line a circle again”. That is the spirit in which Farage shall save our trains.

William Atkinson is assistant content editor at The Spectator
